  7. Runge had large-format engravings made of the drawings of the Times of the Day that became commercially successful and a set of which he presented to his friend, and fellow color enthusiast, Goethe, who hung them in his music room.
Jacques Gondouin and Jean‐Baptiste Lepère, Vendôme Column, 1806‐11

1.    Having risen from complete obscurity to the height of power, Napoleon, who felt the need to bolster his persona and regime through propaganda, turned to the arts after realising its promotional potential. During his reign, numerous buildings and monuments emblematic of his power were constructed in Paris, to commemorate his military exploits. 
2.    The Vendôme column is considered to be the most important of these commemorative monuments. The immediate occasion for the column was Napoleon’s famous victory at Austerlitz where in 1805, he defeated the combined armies of Austria and Russia. 
3.    The 130 ft high column is decorated with a spiralling sculptural relief. The architects Jean-Baptise Lepère and Jacques Gondouin created the column of a stone cylinder, onto which 425  bronze plaques depicted scenes from the Emperor’s campaigns were fixed. These bronze panels were created by a team of about a dozen sculptors. The bronze used to make the monument came from confiscated enemy cannons. 
4.    Originally called the Column of the Great Army, it was erected in one of Paris’s most famous squares, the place Vendôme. The location is significant because here, earlier, had stood a monumental equestrian statue of Louis XVI that was destroyed by revolutionaries in 1792. 
5.    The Vendôme column was inspired by the ancient Roman column of Trajan, which  commemorated the emperor’s victory over the Dacians– a people who lived in Eastern Europe. Both columns were decorated with reliefs depicting the two emperor’s military exploits and surmounted by their full length portraits. Like Trajan, Napoleon is attired in Roman military dress. The Vendôme column therefore indicates Napoleon’s strong identification with ancient Roman imperialism, and his preference for Roman rather than Greek art.
6.    Because of its assertive claim for imperial power, the Vendôme column became one of the most contested monuments of 19thcentury Paris, particularly after the defeat of Napoleon in 1815. With every new regime, the column was altered until it was dismantled during the Paris Commune of 1871. After the fall of the Commune, the new government decided to re-erect it; this was completed in 1875.
John Flaxman, Monument to Admiral Lord Nelson, 1807‐18

Neoclassicism
  1. Flaxman was a leading figure of British Neoclassicism. Early in his career he worked as a modeler for Josiah Wedgwood's ceramic factory.
  2. This was a public commission from the British Parliament to create a statue of Admiral Lord Nelson in Saint Paul's Cathedral, London, as part of a group of sculptures that honored naval and military heroes who fought the French to highlight bravery and patriotism. Nelson's leadership, grasp of strategy, and unconventional tactics brought several decisive British naval victories, particularly during the Napoleonic Wars. He was fatally shot during his victory at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805 and his state funeral was held at St. Paul's Cathedral.
  3. It resembles Ancient Greek portrayals of heroes, with the plinth high above the rest of society. The pedestal is decorated with a relief of ancient river gods. The allegorical female figure wearing armor on the left is Britannia, who guides two children towards Nelson suggesting that they should follow his example.
  4. The lion in the bottom right is representative of the three lions of the English royal coat of arms. He guards Nelson, representing the strength of the nation.
Caspar David Friedrich, Monk by the Sea, 1809‐10

German Romanticism
  1. Friedrich was the sole landscape painter who...had the power to move every part of my soul, the one who created a new genre: the tragedy of landscape. He aimed to produce a Christian art based in nature, divested of standard biblical imagery. Friedrich’s compositions are characterized by metaphysical transcendence. 
  2. The  landscape is the sole carrier of meaning. Influenced by writings of Gotthard Ludwig Kosegarten: personal experience of nature, God's creation, led to a greater understanding of the divine, God manifested in nature. This image reflects religious awe of nature embodied in the spirituality of the monk that marks Kosegarten's writings.
  3. The sublime experience of nature. Overwhelmed by the vastness of the ocean. Art to Friedrich was the center of the highest spiritual effort.
  4. No artistic composition had ever been as uncompromising as this: the main space of the picture seems like an abyss of some kind; there are no boundaries, there is nothing to hold on to, just a sense of floating between night and day, of the lonely monk surrounded by seagulls.
  5. Radical in its conception, painting was a contemporary success, as viewers realized its novelty; "blazed an entirely new trail in the field of his art"
  6. First introduction of Ruckenfigur, a figure seen from the back, engaged in the contemplation of nature; important motif in many of Friedrich's later landscapes; functioned to draw viewer into the painting by inviting viewer to identify with the figure; however, Ruckenfigur also may keep viewer outside of painting as we are always standing behind figure and thus one step removed from the visual experience
  7. German Romanticism was the dominant intellectual movement of German-speaking countries in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, influencing philosophy, aesthetics, literature and criticism. Compared to English Romanticism, the German variety developed relatively late, and, in the early years, coincided with Weimar Classicism (1772-1805). In contrast to the seriousness of English Romanticism, the German variety of Romanticism notably valued wit, humour, and beauty.
Friedrich Overbeck, Portrait of Franz Pforr, 1810

Early Romanticism / Nazarenes
  1. Nazarenes: early Romanticism. Start in Academy of Vienna, 1809: group of young German painters including Overbeck (1789-1869) and Franz Pforr (1788-1812) formed the Brotherhood of St. Luke - patron saint of painters. They rejected Neo-classicism (like Primitives in David’s studio), looked instead to medieval/early Christian art. Interested in what they saw as sincerity (saw this in Albrecht Dürer, Lucas Cranach, as well as Fra Angelico, and Perugino: between middle ages and Renaissance)
  2. Preoccupation with German ancestry: politically motivated nationalism, result of Napoleon’s invasions of Germany. Nostalgia for 1400s-1500s: Germany had leading role in Europe
  3. Moved to vacant monastery of San Isidoro in Rome in 1810 b/c Vienna occupied by French after Battle of Wangram, 1809. Lived like monks: worked in cells during day, ate communally at night, wore loose robes and long hair to look like biblical figures (hence name “Nazarenes”)
  4. Portrait of Pforr: exchanged with Pforr as gift (“friendship pictures”). References to early Christianity including Pforr’s clothing and that of his wife, Gothic cathedral in background, grape vines (reference to eucharist - when the bread and wine supposedly become or symbolize Christ’s body and blood according to the liturgy), Lilies in vase (associated with the annunciation, when according to the the Gospels the Arcangel Gabriel announced to the Virgin Mary that she was pregnant with Christ), Pforr’s personal emblem of skull and cross carved into window (triumph of religion/faith over death). 
  5. Style: reminiscent of Dürer’s self-portraits, other elements of Dutch and Flemish painting. 
  6. While Neoclassical art sought ideal, Romantics: seek to reveal the spiritual essence of subjects.
Théodore Géricault, Charging Chasseur, 1812

French Romanticism

1. This is an early Géricault exemplary of his move away from Classicism
2. Géricault answered Stendhal’s call for a new, Romantic art that was soulful, expressing human emotion in a way that was intelligible to the general public (populism of Romanticism), and that was directly engaged with the present, exploring the tragedies of modern life
3. This is one of his two military paintings: Géricault reached his artistic maturity as the French Empire crumbled, his paintings illustrate the changed fate of France during the course of only a few years: 1812 was the year of Napoleon’s failed Russian campaign, in 1814 Napoleon was deposed and exiled to Elba
4. Unlike David’s Classical Napoleon Crossing the Alps, this chasseur is not seen in profile but diagonally from behind
5. Powerful sense of deep space (unlike David’s relief-like effect), use of dramatic foreshortening effects, reminiscent of Rubens’ Baroque interest in spatial dynamics and free brushstroke (Géricault’s vigorous paint handling is unlike David’s smooth surfaces)
6. This was Géricault’s first exhibited work and an example of his attempt to condense both movement and structure (exhibited only three works during his short life; he died at 32)
Jean­‐Auguste‐Dominique Ingres, Grand Odalisque, 1814

Neoclassicism / Romanticism (French)
  1. A student of Jacques-Louis David, Ingres marks a transition from neoclassicism to romanticism. While the style is far more Neoclassicist, the subject matter is distinctly Romantic. 
  2. Grand Odalisque was commissioned by Queen Caroline Murat of Naples, Napoleon’s sister. In 1819 he submitted it to the salon which was met with hostility for the perversity of representing a nude outside of a narrative context (not a Venus). The image, of a reclining harem woman appeared merely a naked woman on display, turning to look directly at her viewer. 
  3. While the reclining nude was a popular subject matter, in was so under the identity of “Venus.” Ingres insisted through his title, as well as in the objects throughout the scene, that this was an “oriental woman,” not as a symbol of love and beauty, but rather a concubine of a sultan. As such, the work seeks to transport the viewer to an exotic world where Western decorum does not apply. The distance that the Orientalizing of the nude allowed made the image more publicly acceptable.  
  4. The odalisque became a common fantasy figure of Orientalism, a symbol of the “other,” the “erotic” 
  5. The painting’s departure from Davidian Classicism also unsettled visitors to the salon who remarked on the unnatural elongation of the figure’s spine. Ingres used form and line not to faithfully represent reality, but to emphasize the elements of his subject’s interiority, namely, her sensuality. Meanwhile, Ingres depicts the rest of the image with almost photographic accuracy.
  6. The elongated body, and small head reveal the influence of Mannerism on Ingres, particularly the work of Parmigianino. 
  7. A smaller, grisaille version, lives at The Met.
Francisco Goya, Execution of the Rebels on the Third of May, 1808, 1814

1.   Part of Napoleon’s conquests across Europe, his troops poured into Spain in 1807, leading up to a rebellion by Spaniards in 1808. On May 3rd, the Spanish freedom fighters were rounded up and massacred in a bloody execution by the French. Even though Goya had shown French sympathies in the past, the slaughter of his countrymen and the horrors of war made a profound impression on the artist. Part of a pair of canvases commemorating the rebellion of 1808, this painting depicts the moment of execution. 
2.   Shows a row of French soldiers aiming their guns at a Spanish man, who is backed against a country hill in place of an executioner’s wall. A pile of dead bodies lies at his feet, with blood streaming through the street. To his other side, a line of Spanish rebels stretch endlessly into the landscape, covering their eyes to avoid watching the death that awaits them. 
3.   The painting is made powerful in the strong contrast of light between the soldiers and the rebels. The soldiers resemble automatons, merged into a faceless row with identical uniforms and poses. The rebels, lit by light from a lamp, distinguishes their characters. The warm hue indicates their humanity and courage in the face of death. 
4.   This painting has been lauded for its transformation of Christian iconography and its poignant portrayal of man’s inhumanity. The central figure, dressed in a white shirt and light pants, kneeling before his captor, raises his arms up in a gesture that is both desperate and defiant. His expressive face shows anguish that is more sad that terrified, echoing Christ’s prayers and posture on the cross. 
5.   Goya’s history painting is unprecedented since it neither represents a glorious victory nor a heroic battle; artists had previously depicted war with a sense of heroism. Instead, he portrays human slaughter in all its sordidness, an archetypal image of the horrors of war.
J. M.W. Turner, Dido Building Carthage, 1815

English Romanticism
  1. Perhaps the best loved English Romantic artist, known as the "painter of light." He is known for his expressive colorizations, imaginative landscapes and turbulent seascapes in oils, engravings, and watercolors.
  2. This painting of the North African city of Carthage, founded by Dido, its first queen, was inspired by Virgil’s epic poem, the Aeneid. The figure on the left dressed in blue and wearing a diadem is Dido, who fled her country after her husband was murdered and founded Carthage. She is shown visiting the tomb that is beingb built for her dead husband, Sychaeus. Rather than a love-struck or doomed victim, she is portrayed as a commanding figure of strength. The man in a cloak and helmet standing before her is probably Aeneas, the hero of the poem, with whom she will fall in love. Virgil tells of their love affair and of Dido's suicide following his departure.
  3. Turner painted ten major paintings about the Carthaginian empire. The rise and fall of empires preoccupied him throughout his life.
  4. The image embraces a Classical ideal, while alluding to the sublimity of nature through the serene effects of sunlight.
  5. Turner sought to raise the status of landscape painting to that of history painting. To do this he emulated 'Old Master' landscapists like the seventeenth-century French Claude Lorrain and imbued his paintings with historical references, architectural features, human activity, narrative and allegorical meaning - treating a landscape as a history painting, or historical landscape painting.
Benjamin West, Death on the Pale Horse, 1817

American/British Romanticism
  1. West was a British North American history painter around and after the time of the American War of Independence and the Seven Years' War. He was the second president of the Royal Academy in London, serving from 1792 to 1805 and 1806 to 1820. He was offered a knighthood by the British Crown, but declined it, believing that he should instead be made a peer. He said that "Art is the representation of human beauty, ideally perfect in design, graceful and noble in attitude.”
  2.  Entails the Grand Manner: refers to an idealized aesthetic style derived from classical art, and the modern "classic art" of the High Renaissance. In the eighteenth century, British artists and connoisseurs used the term to describe paintings that incorporated visual metaphors in order to suggest noble qualities.
  3. West based this work on the Book of Revelation 6:8, in which the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse—Death, War, Famine, and Pestilence—ravage the earth. The poetical figure of scripture has received from his pencil an aspect still more terrible. Everything in nature is devoured and destroyed: the innocent dove and the wily serpent are reunited by Death.
  4. From Revelations: "Then I looked and saw a pale horse. Its rider's name was Death, and Hades followed close behind. And they were given authority over a fourth of the earth, to kill by sword, by famine, by plague, and by the beasts of the earth."
  5. Possesses powerful romanticism and Mystical, visionary zeal. The antithesis of calm Baroque classicism of West's earlier paintings.  Reveals extraordinary breadth of imaginative abilities. Epitomizes the sublime in both size and subject matter. Edmund Burke's artistic philosophy of "the Sublime," a quality in art that is meant to evoke intense feelings of awe in the viewer.
  6. Not a commissioned work; a new commercial strategy to exhibit painting by itself, and charge entrance fee which shifted monetary value from the possession of an object to its psychological effect on the viewer. A promoted movement toward the democratization of art.
  7. West was elected the Pennsylvania Academy’s first honorary member in 1805. Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts (PAFA) acquired it in 1836.  To raise the necessary seven thousand dollars, the institution had to mortgage its building.
Théodore Géricault, Le Radeau de la Méduse (The Raft of the Medusa), 1819

French Romanticism
  1. Stendhal: art critic, called after 1824 Salon for a new, Romantic art that would “have a soul” and express “some human emotion or spiritual impulse in a vivid manner intelligible to the general public.”Alternative to David’s school of neoclassicism, which “can only paint bodies; it is decidedly inept at painting souls.” Suggested either return to early modern Europe (see Overbeck and the Nazarenes) or representations of the contemporary world. Stendhal pointed to Horace Vernet, but Géricault (1791-1824) was perhaps even more devoted to tragedies of modern life, though died 3 months before Salon of 1824 and his work was not exhibited there.
  2. This icon of Romanticism was based on a 1816 incident: French frigate the Medusa was shipwrecked near West coast of Africa while transporting colonizers and soldiers to Senegal. Lifeboats could only accommodate half of 400 passengers, ship’s carpenter made rudderless raft onto which least valuable passengers were loaded (colonists, low-ranking soldiers). The raft was to be towed by the lifeboats. But, fearful for their own safety, folk in the lifeboats cut the ropes. All but 15 passengers died before they were rescued more 13 days later. The account written by one survivor which detailed the conditions (including starvation and cannibalism) was disseminated widely in the press. 
  3. Captain of ship was appointed due to nepotism of Bourbon nobility, story became rallying cry for the common people who saw themselves in the “less valuable” passengers left adrift on the raft. Became a symbol for France’s lack of competent leader, blaming the disaster on the naval command and, by extension, the entire backward-facing Restoration regime.
  4. Choice of subject: unusual, first contemporary grand-scale history painting that didn’t glorify a ruler/important political event: episode involving common people which illustrates the hope of rescue. The whole composition is oriented toward this hope in a rightward ascent culminating in a black figure, the figurehead of the boat.
  5. Géricault: dedication to detail and accuracy: for Radeau, he studied newspaper stories and and sketched and painted studies of dead bodies in morgue. Neither stories nor these studies directly correspond with final composition: smaller scale of this raft (couldn’t fit 150) amplifies drama of individuals’ experiences. 
  6. Nudity of survivors: classical reference, but they’re not allegories, but rather contemporary people (include details: socks on splayed young man at front left, sailor pants of elderly man holding him)
  7. Radeau (5x7m) exhibited in Salon of 1819 to mixed reviews (4 years after his 2 military paintings exhibited in 1814 Salon, including Charging Chasseur), then exhibited for 6.5 months at Egyptian Hall in London where public could see it for a fee (drew large crowds), and then to Dublin, Ireland for 6 weeks.  
  8. Géricault's work expressed a paradox: how could a hideous subject be translated into a powerful painting, how could the painter reconcile art and reality? Compare to Girodet’s Pygmalion and Galatea, also shown in Salon 1819. The painting had fervent admirers too, who praised its political theme, its liberal position (the advancement of the "negro", the critique of ultra-royalism), and its modernity.
Théodore Géricault, Man Suffering from Delusions of Military Rank, 1819‐22

French Romanticism

1. Part of Géricault’s late work executed shortly before his death in 1824, at a time when he was strapped for cash because the French government still refused to buy the Medusa
2. Paints with an uncompromising realism, showing the men of today in ordinary circumstances of daily life (Stendhal), that foreshadows the work of Courbet
3. One of a series of 10 Portraits of the Insane (Les Monomanes) (5 of which exist today), commissioned by Dr. Georget, a pioneer of modern psychiatry
4. New field of psychiatry: madness was first seen as a mental illness, belief that mental illness coincided with physiognomy, thus studying facial structure could help with the diagnosis
5. Man wears something resembling a Napoleonic military hat, a coin on a makeshift and worn string as if it were a medal of honor, pursed lips, shadow half of the face and averted gaze looking into the unknown (one can never penetrate to the dark recesses of the minds of the insane)
6. The illness “monomania” (suffering from delusional behavior) was coined by Esquinol, a key figure in modern psychiatry
7. Possibly a reference to Napoleon’s failed campaign in 1815
8. Executed with great speed, drawn from life probably in one sitting, hence loose brushwork unlike earlier sculptural style (erratic brushwork mirrors disordered thoughts of sitters)
John Constable, The Hay Wain, 1821

British Romanticism
  1. Constable sought to render landscape naturalistically - rather than striving for ideal beauty or sublime effects he painted images that reminded viewers of familiar, believable sights. That said, he was very focused on creating compositional balance, so would manipulate the image so as to balance color and form within the canvas. 
  2. This is one of many “six-footer” landscape paintings with which he hoped to monumentalize the genre and raise its position within the hierarchy of the Royal Academy. It depicts a rural scene on the River Stour between the English counties of Suffolk and Essex.
  3. Hay Wain represents a leisurely, bucolic summer scene unrepresentative of what was happening in the English countryside in the 1820s. Farm workers were rioting everywhere against heavy taxation and fall in agricultural prices. This pastoral landscape therefore seems to be a nostalgic representation of an idyllic past, appealing to the conservative middle-class visitors of Royal Academy exhibitions. 
  4. This work was made in his London studio from a collection of en plein air oil sketches. He was among the first to embrace the oil sketch. In this way he developed his characteristic style of “spotty pencilling” where he would paint with small dabs of pure color rather than premixing and painting evenly. This allowed him to more effectively render light and the technique became a model for the impressionists and the pointillists.  
  5. Gericault saw this image and was so inspired by it that he spread word of it in France, after which Constable was invited to exhibit the painting at the Paris Salon of 1824, where he was awarded a gold medal. His strikingly fresh, apparently spontaneous transcription of the landscape, described by the French writer Stendhal as “the mirror of nature,” caused a sensation among French painters. Particularly Delacroix, who went back to repaint several of his canvases with Constable’s signature bright dabs of vivid color.  Constable also inspired the Barbizon School.
John Constable, Study of Cirrus Clouds, c. 1822

British Romanticism

1.   Constable was an English landscape painter, contemporary to JMW Turner, but differed in his approach. While Turner covered an extensive range of landscape subjects and travelled widely, Constable stayed close to home and painted the countryside in his native East Anglia, a region northeast of London.
2.   Constable’s primary aim was to render landscapes naturalistically– rather than striving for the ideal beauty or sublime and picturesque effects, he sought to make ‘believable’ pictures that reminded viewers of familiar sites. 
3.   To achieve the illusion of reality, he developed his own method. Like all landscapists he composed his paintings inside his studio, referring to sketches made outdoors. However, unlike other artists who sketched in pencil or watercolour, Constable sketched using oils on paper, and was considered to be the first British artist to do so. It was a complicated process, since oil tubes were not yet available and the artist had to store small amounts of paint in pig bladders to transport. Yet, to Constable, the process was worth the effort as it made it easier to record accurately the effects observed in nature and to translate it faithfully to the finished painting. 
4.   For many years, Constable sketched the sky and clouds at different times under varied weather conditions. His cloud studies are marvels of meteorological observation. Painted on small panels, each study is carefully annotated with the time, date and weather description.
5.   All his sketches were loosely painted in an almost impressionistic manner, to the extent that his finished paintings are considered tedious in comparison to the freely rendered studies. Though his sketches are now regarded as striking for their freshness and immediacy, his contemporaries never saw these works; they were intended for the artist’s own use and never exhibited.
6. Can be compared to Stieglitz’s Equivalents series of clouds in Lake George (1922-34)
Karl Friedrich Schinkel, Altes Museum, Berlin, Germany, 1823-­30

Neoclassical
  1. Commissioned by King Friedrich Wilhelm III of Prussia who supported the Humboldtian ideal for education, that art and a comprehensive cultural education should be available for all citizens.
  2. Built between 1823 and 1830 by the Prussian architect, city planner, and painter, Karl Friedrich Schinkel, it is an important example of neo-classical architecture. Schinkel’s design mixed references to classical architecture, such as the frontal portico adorned with Ionic columns and a large rotunda inspired by the Pantheon's in Rome.
  3. The Altes Museum (Old Museum) was Berlin’s first museum, located on the Lustgarten park in the Museum Island cultural district. It added art as a fourth element to the open rectangle of politics (Berlin Palace), military (Armory), and church (Berlin Cathedral).
  4. The building was severely damaged during World War II, and was re-opened in 1966 after a major restoration, thereafter it housed contemporary art of the GDR until reunification.
  5. Today it houses the Collection of Classical Antiquities of the National Museums in Berlin, renowned for its vast collections of Greek, Etruscan, and Roman antiquities.
  6. Schinkel's style, in his most productive period, is defined by a turn to Greek rather than Imperial Roman architecture, an attempt to turn away from the style that was linked to the recent French occupiers of the Napoleonic Wars.
François-­Joseph Heim, Charles X Distributing Prizes after the Salon of 1824, 1825

Bourbon Restoration Period
  1. Heim was the pre-eminent official painter of the Bourbon Restoration, is one of the least known painters to have achieved fame and success in France in the 1820s.
  2. 1816: Royal Academy restored, restructured as Academy of Fine Arts; 1819: School of Fine Arts, academicians, were past middle age and uninterested in innovation. Charles X - Bourbon monarchy, King 1824-30.
  3. Monumental canvases primarily government commissions, usually painted by well-established Academy members; during Restoration, young artists began to submit large works independently, realizing small works gained little attention from critics and viewers.
  4. This image demonstrates the overpowering nature of large canvases next to smaller works. Followers of David dominated Salon until 1824 and the rise of the Romantics.
  5. The period of French history following the first fall of Napoleon in 1814, and his final defeat in the Hundred Days in 1815, until the July Revolution of 1830. The brothers of the executed Louis XVI came to power and reigned in highly conservative fashion. Exiled supporters of the monarchy returned to France. They were nonetheless unable to reverse most of the changes made by the French Revolution and Napoleon.
Jean‐Pierre Cortot, Marie‐Antoinette Seeking Solace with Religion, c. 1825

Chapelle Expiatoire, Paris

Bourbon Restoration: Eclectic Historicism / Baroque Revival (?)
  1. Chapelle Expiatoire (Expiatory Chapel): monumental work of architecture and sculpture commissioned by Louis XVIII of France and supposedly dedicated to the expiation (atonement) of the French people for having sinned against God by killing King and Queen (reminder: according to French monarchy, kings ruled by divine right). Built on grounds of cemetery where Louis XVII and Marie Antoinette were originally interred post-execution. 
  2. Hearken to the holy union of "Dieu et le Roi" though anticlerical sentiments were widespread among the people of France at the time. 
  3. Under Louis XVIII: stylistic return to pre-Revolutionary (and therefore pre-Classical) past. Designed by Royal Architect (former First Imperial Architect) Pierre-François-Léonard Fonaine. Styles in chapel mixed Graeco-Roman, Etruscan, Renaissance, medieval (early eclectic historicism)
  4. Juxtaposed with statue The Apotheosis of Louis XVI inside chapel. Marie-Antoinette’s last letter, written to Louis XVI’s sister Elisabeth, is quoted on the pedestal: “I die in the apostolic Roman Catholic religion.” 
  5. Cortot (1787-1843) was one of most successful sculptors of period. Later commissioned by Louis Philippe to create statue for the Arc de Triomphe: The Apotheosis of Napoleon I (The Triumph of 1810), 1833–1836.
  6. Portrays the former queen not soft-faced and decked in ornate jewels and hair dressings as in Vigée-LeBrun’s portrait, nor aging and haggard as in David’s sketch. Rather, youthful, her hair loose, ermine stole and fleur-de-lys pattern on her dress (symbols of French monarchy and Bourbon dynasty), but crown has fallen to her side (an allusion to beheading?). 
  7. Allegorical figure of Religion which Marie-Antoinette clasps is a timeless, stoic counterpoint to former queen’s anxiety and specificity. Neoclassical vs Baroque styles, respectively. 
  8. Baroque: favored for portraying royalty; revived for portraits of restored Bourbon monarchs, including Paulin Guérin’s Portrait of Louis XVIII, Salon of 1819.
Camille Corot, Island and Bridge of San Bartolomeo, Rome 1826‐1828

French Barbizon School
1. This is an example of Corot’s early work produced during his stay in Italy in the late 1820s, where he was painting in plein-air (outdoors, directly from nature), mastering light and atmospheric effects
2. Corot later became the greatest landscape painter of his time, producing both large-scale historic landscapes and mid-sized French scenes for middle-class buyers
3. Landscape painting was the most popular genre during the July Monarchy (up to 30% of all salon paintings), bought to decorate the homes of a prospering middle class
4. References the Neoclassical tradition: organized in interlocking horizontals and verticals, use of a narrow palette of ochres and browns
5. Corot innovated the plein-air technique and later popularized it in Paris (anticipating the innovations of the Impressionists)
6. Little demand for these sketches on the market, which remained in his own possession
7. Corot is part of the Barbizon School = French landscape painters who embraced a naturalist style during the July Monarchy; its center was in the small village called Barbizon around the circle of Théodore Rousseau
Eugene Delacroix, Death of Sardanapalus, 1827‐28

Musée du Louvre, Paris

Romanticism (France)
  1. Unlike Gericault’s focus on reality and the present, Delacroix was far more interested in the past, the fictional and the exotic, often imagining scenes from literature and poetry. This work was inspired by a play by British Romantic poet Lord Byron titled Sardanapalus. 
  2. His interest in Orientalism is best demonstrated by this work which was exhibited at Salon of 1927-28. In this work, Delacroix envisions the moments before Assyrian King Sardanapalus committed suicide upon the siege of his palace by rebels. In the painting, he watches stoicly as he ordered the murder all wives, pages, horses and dogs, and the destruction all his treasures, before the rebels had a chance to steal them. 
  3. The King is depicted as both judge and executioner, actor and spectator, reclining on the bed in a perfectly still pose that evokes a classical or Renaissance statue. Around his stillness, figures are confused with horror, physical tension building up dramatically along the diagonal.
  4. The painting is composed along a diagonal from upper left to lower right which, along with Delacroix’s sweeping brushstroke and vibrant contrasting colors, unsettles the composition and creates a sense of dynamism, chaos and violence. The dramatic foreshortening of the painting pulls the scene towards the viewer. 
  5. The city can be seen burning in the distance. 
  6. Delacroix’s use of extreme color and contrasts of light glorifies the materiality of the subject in a way characteristic of Romanticism: smooth flesh, shimmering fabrics, gleaming jewels and gold.  
  7. The work seems to exemplify Romanticism in its Orientalist thematics and sublime horror as well as in the dynamic composition, free brushwork and explosive color, but was interpreted as too imaginative and disorderly for many of his contemporary critics. As one critic wrote, “he wanted to compose disorder, and he forgot that disorder itself has a logic.”
Charles Philipon, Les Poires (The Pears) Illustration in Le Charivari, 1831

French political cartoon/realism
1.     By the early 1830s, there was a dramatic expansion of print media, coinciding with a dramatic rise in literacy rates and improvements in paper making and printing, which made newspapers cheaper and easier to produce. Due to the increase in newspapers that carried illustrations, the new popular media had a strong visual component. The newly invented techniques of wood engraving and lithography enabled a mass reproduction of images. 
2.     Charles Philipon was a French political cartoonist, lithographer and editor of two journals that were  known to be satirical: La Caricature, founded in 1830 and Le Charivari, founded in 1832. Both journals however, came under fire as the censorship laws during Louis Philippe's reign grew increasingly oppressive for political caricaturists, several of whom were arrested and put on trial. 
3.     While in court in 1831, Philipon argued that cartoons published in published in his journals should not be interpreted as harmful to the king because any object can be drawn to resemble the king’s face or anything else for that matter. He thus chose to prove his point by sketching a pear. 
4.     Together with his contemporary caricaturist, Honoré Daumier, he developed Les Poires which became the most famous satirical emblem of the July Monarchy. It began as a caricature of Louis Philippe, whose heavy-jowled face had the outline of a pear. 
5.     The symbolism itself is layered in multiple meanings, one of which is the slang meaning of the French word poire meaning fathead. It further refers to Louis Philippe as nothing but a figurehead, faceless and voiceless, out-ruled by his ministers.
Honoré Daumier, Gargantua, 1831

French political cartoon/realism
  1. The prolific and socially conscious artist, Honoré Daumier, highlighted socioeconomic distinctions in the newly modernized urban environment in paintings and lithographs. He produced thousands of graphic works, satirizing government officials and the manners of the bourgeoisie.
  2. This caricature was inspired by the French Renaissance author François Rabelais' satirical novel, Gargantua, whose main character is an obscene and vulgar giant.  Here, Daumier depicts the French King Louis Phillippe as Gargantua.
  3. Like Rabelais, Daumier delved into social commentary. Louis-Philippe is shown with a pear-shaped head on his throne swallowing bags of coins which are carried up a plank that stretches from the ground to his mouth. At the foot of the plank is a crowd of poor men and women handing over their money. Louis-Philippe known for his spending and corruption is shown giving smaller amounts to the henchmen at his sides and expelling public honors to his supporters.
  4. Published in the comic journal La Caricature (1830-1843), the artist and editors landed six months in prison because of the lithograph's unfavorable portrayal of the King.
Eugène Delacroix, Liberty Leading The People (The 28th of July), 1830 (Salon of 1831)

Musée du Louvre, Paris

French Romanticism
  1. Delacroix was a French Romantic artist regarded from the outset of his career as the leader of the French Romantic school. In contrast to David, Delacroix felt classical literature and art did not excite the emotions. He looked to the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Milton, Shakespeare, Dante, Goethe, Byron, and Scott. He was a literary painter rather than history painter. Art and poetry offered an element of fantasy and space for the imagination to explore.
  2. Exhibited at the Salon of 1831. Liberty commemorates three-day revolution in 1830 that led to the end of the Restoration and the reign of Louis-Phillippe (r. 1830-1848).
  3. The figure of Liberty is also viewed as a symbol of France and the French Republic known as Marianne. She is holding the tricolour flag, which again became France's national flag after these events. Marianne has been the national personification of the French Republic since the French Revolution, as a personification of liberty and reason, and a portrayal of the Goddess of Liberty. Marianne is displayed in many places in France and holds a place of honour in town halls and law courts.
  4. Unique to Delacroix's oeuvre, as it depicts a contemporary event and uniquely combines images of real people with an allegorical figure. While some contemporaries were shocked by the combination, others praised the artist for having invented a "new allegorical language"
  5. Delacroix is all about color and looser brushwork. Ingres and others continued Classicism (linearists) and Romantics like D. were all about color (colorists). Vigor and enthusiasm in this painting comes from the reds, the quickness and looseness of the brush and the heavy smoke. 
  6. "July Monarchy" crucial period for French culture and art: starts with the divisions of Classical and Romantic art and ends with the synthesis of the two; landscape, historical, and Orientalist genre painting become popular; and "high art" and popular visual culture (books, newspapers) become popular. Bourbon Restoration periods ends with July Revolution and Louis Phillipe takes the throne of France, overthrowing Charles X.
François Rude, The Departure of Volunteers of 1792, 1833‐36

Arc de Triomphe, Paris

French Romanticism
  1. After the overthrow of the Bourbon monarchy in July 1930, Louis-Philippe replaced Charles X: constitutional monarchy known as the July Monarchy (1830-48). Under his reign: rise + expansion of the middle class, beginning of socialism (corrective to poverty induced by Industrial Revolution + capitalism - see Daumier’s Gargantua. Louis-Philippe’s downfall: failure to attend to needs of urban proletariat in particular -> 1848 revolution.)
  2. Louis Philippe completed a number of Napoleonic monuments previously left unfinished, including the Arc de Triomphe, in hopes of harnessing opposition groups who heroized Napoleon. (Arc was originally designed in 1806 by Jean Chalgrin, left unfinished in 1815 when Napoleon was defeated.)
  3. Commissioned large sculptures for arch’s pillars, including Departure of Volunteers of 1792. Louis Philippe hoped to inspire nationalism like that of the volunteers who defended France against Austro-Prussian invaders after the revolution. 
  4. Sculpture is also known as The Marseillaise (the title of French national anthem, first sung by one of the volunteers). Second to last verse includes the lines: “Sacred love of the Fatherland, / Lead, support our avenging arms / Liberty, cherished Liberty, / Fight with thy defenders!”
  5. Neoclassical: allegorical figure of Liberty-France (see: Delacroix, Liberty Leading the People) and warriors whose clothing and weaponry seem to reference the Gauls, ancient inhabitants of France (see: Nazarenes and nationalism)
  6. Classical device: bilateral symmetry. But rather than earlier stoic monumental sculpture: animated, dramatic poses show influence of Romanticism.
Charles Fourier, Phalanstère, c. 1834

French utopian architecture (Romanticism?)
1. Plan of a building for a self-contained socialist utopian community
2. Phalanstère is a combination of phalange (military unit) and monastère
3. Fourier was a French philosopher and influential early socialist thinker, one of the founders of utopian socialism, many of his radical thinking later became mainstream (i.e. he is credited with coining the word feminism in 1837)
4. Inspired a whole movement of international communities: declared cooperation to be the secret of social success, workers would live in communities in which they were recompensed for their labors according to their contribution
5. Phalanstères were “grand hotels” for cooperative communities: four-level apartment complexes where the richest had the uppermost apartments and the poorest had a ground-floor residence (influenced Haussmann buildings); wealth was determined by one's job (assigned based on interest of individual), jobs people might not enjoy doing would receive higher pay (attempt to eradicate poverty, which Fourier saw as the cause for social disorder)
6. Jews were assigned to perform farm work and not trade, which Fourier saw as the source of all evil (antisemite)
7. Structure: central dining and meeting rooms, one wing for noisy labor and children, one wing for a ballroom and rooms for meetings with outsiders
8. Belief that architecture can influence society for the better
9. Le Corbusier adapted the concept of the phalanstère for his Unité d’Habitation in Marseille
10.  Fourier is an example of socialist ideas outside of a Marxist mainstream: i.e. after the Surrealists broke with the communist party, André Breton returned to the work of Fourier in 1947
Carl Blechen, View of Roofs and Gardens, c. 1835, Nationalgalerie, Berlin

1. This is an example of direct painting before a view from his window in Berlin, unromantic in its faithful depiction of an everyday view. The view is a mass of shrubs, fences and is largely blocked by a roof top in the foreground. The palette is reduced to mainly browns and muddy greens. 
  2. But despite the seeming directness and spontaneity of the painting, it is highly deliberate in its composition: the angle of the foreground roof is part of a series of diagonals that pivot around a central hut; the sharp edge of light on the bottom of that roof emphasizes the modulation of tone in the garden behind it. 
  3. This sort of free and rather spontaneous painting was further developed by Adolph Menzel, another outsider artist 
  4. Blechen repudiated romanticism and was a proponent of a new realism.
Thomas Cole, The Oxbow (The Connecticut River Near Northhampton), 1836

Hudson River School
1.     This is a seminal painting by American painter Thomas Cole, founder of the Hudson River School, a movement that merged elements of American scientific realism with idealised even religious interpretations of nature from European romanticism. 
2.     The painting depicts a romantic panorama of the Connecticut River Valley just after a thunderstorm. The composition moves from a dark wilderness with shattered tree trunks on rugged cliffs in the foreground, with overhanging storm clouds on the left to a light-filled and peaceful landscape on the right. It has been interpreted as a confrontation between wilderness and civilisation. 
3.     The view Cole sought to paint was a particularly difficult one, as its panoramic breadth extended beyond the width of typical landscape paintings of the period. To resolve this, Cole stitched together two separate views from Mt. Holyoke crate a synthetic rather than faithful image of the scene. 
4.     Cole’s interest in this subject possibly dates from his 1829 trip to Europe during which he made an exact tracing of the view published in a book of etchings by British officer Basil Hall. Hall criticised American’s inattentiveness to their scenery, to which Cole responded with this landscape that lauds the uniqueness of American scenery by encompassing the union of the picturesque and the sublime. 
5.     Although ambiguous about the subjugation of the land, here Cole juxtaposes untamed wilderness with the pastoral Settlement to emphasise the possibilities of the national landscape, pointing to the future prospects of the American nation. Cole’s construction of a scene charged with moral significance is reinforced in his insertion of a self-portrait in  the middle, painting the Oxbow. He is an American producing American art, in communion with American scenery.
Louis‐Jacques‐Mandé Daguerre, Boulevard du Temple, Paris, c. 1838

Early Photography
 
  1. Daguerreotype: first publicly-announced method of photography: Daguerre described it in September 1835 edition of the Parisian magazine Journal des artistes. Perfected by 1839, the process had become relatively simple, and was widely-adopted. 
  2. His innovative technique consisted of exposing a silver-plated sheet of copper and sensitized with iodine vapors, exposed in a large box camera, developed in mercury fumes, and stabilized (or fixed) with salt water or sodium thiosulphate (popularly known as hypo).
  3. Daguerreotypes were not multiples made from negatives: exposure was direct transfer of light through lens onto plate.
  4. Daguerre’s Paris Boulevard shows the advantages of the new technique. There is far more detail than in Talbot's photographs (visible cracked plaster and distant commercial inscriptions), who had invented the salted paper and calotype processes and required longer exposure times. 
  5. Long exposure time, initially between 3-15 minutes meant that the people hurrying along sidewalks did not register on the photograph: the streets appeared mostly empty, except for a shoe shiner and his patron, at the bottom left: among the first people to be candidly caught on film, possibly the first photographic register of a human being.
  6. From its birth, photography had a dual character—as a medium of artistic expression and as a powerful scientific tool—and Daguerre promoted his invention on both fronts. Several of his earliest plates were still-life compositions of plaster casts after antique sculpture, but he also photographed an arrangement of shells and fossils with the same deliberation, and used the medium for other scientific purposes as well.
  7. Fewer than twenty-five securely attributed photographs by Daguerre survive after a fire burned down his laboratory in March 1839.
Christen Købke, View from the Embankment of Lake Sortedam, 1838. Statens Museum for Kunst, Copenhagen

Biedermeier culture and the Danish Golden Age
  1. Kobke was a Danish painter and one of the best-known artists from the Golden Age of Danish Painting. Interested in national matters and national identity.
  2. Recalls work of Caspar David Friedrich, particularly with the Rückenfigur (a figure seen from the back and engaged with nature), but has more subdued and mundane character; not vast, untamed nature of Romantics, but domesticated and civilized nature. The women are not in awe of nature but look to a boat of tourists and civilization on the opposite shore. 
  3. The painting was created at a time when national sentiments grew greatly in strength and scope. Indeed, the work cultivates the atmospheric and the romantic (the Danish Golden Age was inspired from the German Romanticism), while the flag accentuates the fact that we are looking at a Danish suburban landscape. Further, the flag links the painting to the nationalist sentiments that grew greatly in strength and scope around this time. Købke had a similar painting from the Sortedam Lake exhibited at Charlottenborg in 1838.
  4. The Biedermeier culture toned down the Romantics and embraced sentimentality rather than extreme emotion, relaxed hikes rather than nature worship, and community rather than individualism. Biedermeier morals/ mentality extended to countries such as Denmark, where this was painted
  5. Biedermier culture existed from the Congress of Vienna to the Revolution of 1848. The term comes from fictitious poet, Gottlieb Biedermeier, whose poems were in satirical newspaper in Munich in 1850s. Its simple verses celebrated bourgeois values such as simplicity, frugality, hard work and piety. Bieder means plain, solid and unpretentious. Meier refers to an administrator of an estate, that is a man who earned his money not with his hands (like a peasant) but with his brains. Art was an integral part of the Biedermeier home.
  6. Danish Golden Age covers a period of exceptional creative production in Denmark, especially during the first half of the 19th century. Although Copenhagen had suffered from fires, bombardment and national bankruptcy, the arts took on a new period of creativity catalysed by Romanticism from Germany. A distinct national style for the first time since the Middle Ages; the period lasted until the middle of the century. It has a style drawing on Dutch Golden Age painting, especially its landscape painting, and depicting northern light that is soft but allows strong contrasts of colour. The treatment of scenes is typically an idealized version of reality, but unpretentiously so, appearing more realist than is actually the case. Interior scenes, often small portrait groups, are also common, with a similar treatment of humble domestic objects and furniture, often of the artist's circle of friends. Little Danish art was seen outside the country (indeed it mostly remains there to this day) although the Danish-trained leader of German Romantic painting Caspar David Friedrich was important in spreading its influence in Germany.

J.M.W. Turner, Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On (later also known as Slave Ship), 1840.
Museum of Fine Arts, Boston

English Romanticism (?) / Royal Academy

  1. Turner (1775-1851) began career as a watercolorist like many British landscape artists at the time, but also worked in oils (Royal Academy considered watercolor to be a less serious medium; he studied there, became an Academician, and eventually taught there)
  2. Turner was interested in the ways that landscapes could bear meaning like history paintings.  eg, The Shipwreck, 1805 - man’s insignificance vs nature, and Snow Storm: Hannibal Crossing the Alps, 1812, inspired by Napoleon’s invasion of Italy in 1800 - Turner condemned Hannibal for wasting so many men’s lives. 
  3. Slavers… is based on true story of slave ship Zong in 1780s: captain threw overboard sick and dying enslaved people to collect insurance money (somewhat common practice). Slavery abolished in Britain 1807, and in British colonies in 1833, but still legal in France and America, among other places, when Turner painted Slavers Throwing... Painting has also been read as broader commentary on man’s violence against other men for the sake of profit. 
  4. Demands durational and close looking: seems initially to be a sunset, choppy waves, boat - sublime power of nature over man. But: carnage of manacled legs and hands emerging from waves surrounded by clouds of red (blood?) and schools of wide-mouthed fish. Result not of nature’s violence but man’s. 
  5. When Turner exhibited Slavers Throwing... at the Royal Academy in 1840, he paired it with the following extract from his unfinished and unpublished poem "Fallacies of Hope" (1812): "Aloft all hands, strike the top-masts and belay; / Yon angry setting sun and fierce-edged clouds / Declare the Typhon's coming. / Before it sweeps your decks, throw overboard / The dead and dying - ne'er heed their chains / Hope, Hope, fallacious Hope! / Where is thy market now?"
  6. John Ruskin, prominent art critic, was the first owner of Slavers Throwing… and was a staunch admirer of Turner’s work. He wrote, "If I were reduced to rest Turner's immortality upon any single work, I should choose this."

Charles Barry and A.W. N. Pugin, Houses of Parliament
rebuilding begun 1840, London

Victorian Gothic Revival
1. A fire in 1834 destroyed the old Houses of Parliament in Westminster Palace; the competition to rebuild them was won by the already well-established Barry, who worked in the eclectic historicist style and was admirer of the Gothic style of the early Tudor period: it showed more moral integrity and spiritual quality than pagan Greek and Roman art
2. Pugin, 23 at the time, was a Catholic architect devoted to the Gothic style, was responsible for the interior design: employed best wood and stone carvers, metal smiths, tile makers
3. Pugin is said to have been displeased with the result, having remarked: “All Grecian, sir. Tudor details on a Classic body.”
4. Accompanied by a commission for monumental frescos (many by William Dyce) to counteract a perceived “degeneration” of art to middle-class entertainment (during a time in which the middle class became the main consumer of art and dictated its style)
5. Gothic Revival was an architectural movement that began in the late 1740s in England, peaked by the 1870s and died by the 1930s; characterized by stone and brick structures, pointed arches, steep gables, large windows, decorative panels; it constituted a return to the past in the face of anxieties over industrialization; was associated with Catholicism and more conservative attitudes (as opposed to the liberal left attitudes of Neoclassicism)

Edwin Landseer, Windsor Castle in Modern Times, 1841‐45
Royal Collection, St. James’s Palace, London

Victorian (Britain)
  1. The painting was commissioned by Queen Victoria and was hung in their sitting room at Windsor Castle.
  2. Depicts young Queen Victoria dressed like a middle class woman of the period, greeting Albert who has just returned from a hunt. Vicky (first child) plays with her pet bird.
  3. Victoria promoted images of herself as “another British citizen,” rather than as royalty, espousing the same ideals and values as the rest of the nation. The image reflects the virtues held high by Victorian middle-class society: domestic harmony, spousal fidelity, masculine “character,” and feminine devotion and modesty.
  4. Victoria exemplifies these feminine characters, greeting her husband with love and reverence (note the bouquet of flowers she presents him with) but in standing in front of him, asserts her status as ruling monarch.
  5. Also reflected a growing popularity of dog paintings as dogs became seen more as companions than merely working or sporting animals. The inclusions of the royal dogs also worked to make the family appear more relatable – engaging in a middle-class hobby of owning dogs (think of Bo and the Obamas!). Landseer was a leading animal painter of the period.
  6. Modelled off a type of painting called Conversation piece in which a family would be positioned in an informal setting engaged in conversation.
Jean‐Auguste­‐Dominique Ingres, Odalisque with Slave, 1842

French Romanticism
1.     Ingres was a French artist who painted a number of harem scenes during his long career. This work exemplifies the obsession for Orientalist subject matter shared by several French artists of the Romantic era, notably Ingres’ rival Eugène Delacroix. 
2.     The image depicts a nude odalisque, a musician and a eunuch in a harem interior. The painting was composed in Rome, where the artist lived from 1835 to 1841. The odalisque was painted from a life drawing Ingres had made years earlier and the musician was painted from a model posed in the studio. 
3.     Although unlike artists like Delacroix, Ingres had never travelled outside of Europe, he became fascinated by writings about Turkish society, mixing details from travel writing with his own fantasies. The image arguable reveals more about the European imagination than it does about the social reality of a private Middle Eastern residence. 
4.     Ingres referred to engravings and Persian miniatures to craft the décor in his paintings. Here the oriental implications owe less to the use of colour than the voluptuous arabesques. 
5.     Stemming from a fascination with private spaces like the harem accessible only to women, the body of the sequestered Middle Eastern woman becomes a site for exotic fantasies in European art and literature.
Henri Labrouste, Bibliothèque Ste. Geneviève, Paris, 1843‐50

Neo-Renaissance and Rationalist Architecture
  1. Labrouste was a French architect from the famous École des Beaux-Arts school of architecture. After a six-year stay in Rome, Labrouste established an architectural training workshop, which soon became known for rationalism. He became noted for his use of iron-frame construction and was one of the first to realize the importance of its use.
  2. Library in the place du Panthéon, Paris.  It is the first public building to have a frankly exposed structural iron frame. Wrought iron and cast iron, used to great structural and aesthetic effect in engineering works since the late eighteenth century, were still widely regarded as unsuitable for legitimate architecture (except for decorative details like balustrades or ornamental hardware)
  3. The library held the collection of books and documents from the former Abbey de Sainte-Geneviève, founded in the sixth century. The new library was to be part of an urban renewal scheme around the Panthéon.
  4.  A Parisian, Labrouste had studied architecture at L'École des Beaux-Arts from 1819 to 1824 and developed notions of "romantic rationalism." The St. Geneviève Library hybridizes neo-Renaissance and rationalist architecture, the first through its composition and decorative details, the second by the refreshing expression of internal organization and function in the design of the facades
  5. The two-story rectangular building follows a straightforward architectural program: a comparted ground floor houses library stacks and rare book storage areas that flank a central foyer. A stair leads to a vast reading room that occupies the entire upper story. That airy space is lit by forty-six huge high-level. Across its width, it is divided by a central spine of elegantly slender cast-iron Ionic columns standing on short piers. The columns, braced longitudinally with filigree arches, support decorative openwork cast-iron round arches, designed by Labrouste. The transverse arches in turn directly carry barrel vaults formed by plaster reinforced by iron mesh on a network of joists. Relatively modest facades incorporate Renaissance elements, such as the virtual arcade of almost continuous windows on the upper level.
  6. Early use of indoor gas lighting, indicated by reliefs of gas lights next to the main entrance.
  7. Rejected the concept of an ideal architecture and instead saw architecture as a rational construction approach defined by the materials and purpose of the structure.
William Henry Fox Talbot, Trafalgar Square, London, During the Erection of the Nelson Column, 1844

Early Photography/Victorian Era
 
1. Talbot was an English member of parliament, scientist, inventor and a pioneer of photography. He began photographic experiments (photogenic drawing) in 1834. In 1841 he patented his discovery of the calotype (Greek for beautiful impression), like this salted paper print from a paper calotype negative. His innovative method used a high-quality writing paper, photosensitized with chemical solutions, placed in a camera, and exposed to light to create a negative from which many positive prints could be made. This is the basic principle behind nearly all subsequent photography until the digital age. 
2. The calotype's advantage over the daguerreotype was that it could be printed on paper rather than silver foil, and that it was possible to make multiple prints from a single negative, its disadvantages were lack of sharpness and clarity.
3. Nelson's Column (1840-43) is a monument in Trafalgar Square in London built to commemorate Admiral Horatio Nelson, who died during his great victory at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805 (British navy victorious against France and Spain during Napoleonic Wars.) Talbot’s photograph captures the instance of a double construction, that of the image of London through one of its most recognizable sights (Trafalgar Square), and of photography as a medium, with the invention of an image-making process.
4. Printed placards on the wood fencing allow dating it precisely. Among the playbills is an advertisement for the Theater Royal Lyceum's new season opening on Easter Monday, April 8, 1844. 
5. The same year, Talbot published The Pencil of Nature in 6 installments (1844-46), the first major photographically illustrated book (photography, for Talbot, was the titular Pencil of Nature). He explained photographic process of image-making through the “agency of light alone,” and suggested uses for the new medium. 
6. The introduction of glass negatives in 1851 precipitated a decline in the use of paper negatives. Artists who still chose to work with paper negatives did so because they preferred its aesthetic qualities—a softening of detail and a massing of light and shadow—or because of its practical advantages for travel photography and hot climates. Unlike glass negatives, paper negatives could be prepared well in advance of their use and developed long after, eliminating the need for a complete portable darkroom.
7. The calotype distinguished its practitioners as artists, distinct from commercial photographers, who preferred the faster process and sharper images of glass negatives.

Jean‐Baptiste‐Camille Corot, Fishing with Net, Evening, 1847 
Musée Fabre, Montpellier

Barbizon School (France)
  1. Ever increasing popularity of landscape paintings by mid 1800s, constituting 25-30% of exhibited paintings at the Salon.
  2. Corot was trained in Neo-classical tradition and developed a highly personal vision of the landscape.
  3. Corot was admired at the Salon for the mastery of his lighting and atmospheric effects. He is able to suggest the atmosphere of a particular time of day (Evening in the case of this painting)
  4. His landscapes were based on personal observation in which he studied nature in the open air and as such have a convincing sense of freshness and immediacy.
  5. Use of fresh greens and a light feathery touch for rendering of foliage suggests springtime
  6. Resembles the landscapes of the artists of the Barbizon School in its naturalism, but adds a wistful poetic quality that made Corot the most popular landscapist of the 19th C.
  7. The work depicts the unchanged, timeless subject of fishing but transforms the scene into an idyllic image that emphasizes harmony between man and nature.

Thomas Couture, Romans of the Decadence, 1847
Musée d’Orsay, Paris

French History Painting / Romanticism (?)
  1. Shown at the 1847 Salon to great success - last Salon of Louis Philippe’s July Monarchy (1830-48). Monumental painting
  2. Stylistically juxtaposes Romanticism and Classicism. (Recalls Raphael.) Artists at time were questioning the relevance of Classical style and moralizing subjects (as Diderot and other Enlightenment-era thinkers suggested) to modern life in a rapidly industrializing country.  
  3. As teacher, Couture advocated that his students pursue modern subjects: “these are our new subjects. Our workmen have not been represented; they remain yet to be put on canvas.”
  4. Couture was a Republican. Quoted two lines from Roman poet Juvenal in catalogue for 1847 Salon: "Crueller than war, vice fell upon Rome and avenged the conquered world.” Painting is seen as thinly-veiled allusion to the excesses of the nouveau riche bourgeoisie: just as (according to contemporaneous belief) the Roman empire fell because of the decadence of its ruling class, so too was France suffering because of the excesses of the rich and powerful. 
  5. Antique statues: Rome’s (France’s) heroic history, a historical and stylistic counterpoint to the decadence of the present depicted in the painting. Statues have been read as passing judgment on the revelers, one of whom (in the foreground) appears to mockingly toast the nude at the center of the composition. Loss of sight of revolutionary/republican ideals displayed in sculpture and architecture - slip into myth/history. 
  6. After 1848 revolution - compare with Courbet’s A Burial at Orneans, focus on present rather than historical imagery.

Francois­‐Auguste Biard, Four O’Clock at the Salon, Salon of 1847
Musee du Louvre, Paris

French Romanticism / July Monarchy
1. Under the July Monarchy (reign of Louis Philippe 1830-1848) the Parisian Salon became an extremely popular public event, with submissions and visitors increasing dramatically; they became annual and no longer bi-annual events
2. Art criticism and salon reviews became a literary genre, with important authors like Baudelaire (made his debut in 1846) writing art criticism for journals
3. Popular genres: historic genre paintings, Orientalist scenes, portraits, landscapes
4. The grandes machines (big history paintings) still dominated the salons, but with the prospering of the middle classes during the July Monarchy, more and more small and mid-size works were submitted for potential middle-class buyers (compare with the grandes machines in the salon painting of Heim, 1825, Restoration period)
5. The salons increasingly became a marketplace (still very few commercial art galleries existed), although they did not list prices, only artists’ addresses
6. While it shows similarly stuffed walls, the painting differs from earlier salon paintings (Heim, 1825) by its depiction of a more middle-class audience (different dress) and a scene of chaos and dramatic commotion as opposed to the orderly stacking of figures with a clear central point of focus (influence of Romanticism)
Jean‐Louis Ernest Meissonier, Memory of Civil War, or Barricade in the Rue de la Mortellerie, June 1848, 1848

French Realism
1.     The Revolution of 1848 began as a response to the mass unemployment and food shortage during the reign of Louis Philippe. In June 1848, the unemployed took to the streets and were joined by crowds of students, artisans and workers. The government sent in troops, leaving 1500 rebels dead and resulting in mass violence and brutality during what is known as the ‘June Days.’ 
2.     The Revolution had a profound impact on artists like Jean-Louis Ernest Meissonier, who created works mourning the revolution and its atrocities. Memory of Civil War was exhibited at the Salon of 1850-51. 
3.     Although it was painted after the fact, with the help of models, it was based on a scene that Meissonier had witnessed first-hand. During the June Days he had stormed the rebel barricades as an artillery captain in the National Guard. He remembers seeing defenders being shot down, hurled out of windows, the ground strewn with corpses, the streets red with blood. 
4.     Meissonier’s painting shows a back street in Paris, with its cobblestones dug up for the construction of a barricade. The rebels, shot dead, are piled amidst the rubble. Meissonier’s argument is a reversal from Delacroix’s barricade scene in Liberty Leading the People. While Delacroix’s painting suggests that a victorious revolution is worth the sacrifices of a few victims, this painting emphasises the civil tragedy of a revolution in which Frenchmen are killing each other. 
5.     The sober realism of Meissonier’s work is very different from the Romantic enthusiasm of Delacroix’s paintings, making it more in tune with the newly emerging Realism movement.
Gustave Courbet, The Stonebreakers, 1849‐50

French Realism 
  1. Courbet led the Realism movement in mid 19th-century French painting, characterized by subjects painted from everyday life in a naturalistic manner (meaning subjects outside the high art tradition). Committed to painting only what he could see, he rejected Academicism and Romanticism. He promoted socialist ideas by writing politically motivated essays and dissertations.
  2. The painting was inspired by a scene he witnessed on the road to Chateau de Saint Denis of two men crushing stones into gravel for later use to pave roads. Courbet stated, “Alas, in that class, that is how one begins and how one ends up... it is rare to see a more complete expression of misery." His comment on endemic poverty and the lack of upward mobility during the July Monarchy is represented by the old and young men, telling of the fact that if born poor one remains poor. Notice cooking pot and tattered clothing.
  3. It displays unusually rough brushwork, in opposition to the polished Academic/Neoclassicist style still popular, it displays a frontal perspective and proximity that makes it appear more "real," leading contemporary critics to call it "ruthless naturalism."
  4. The faceless/anonymous depictions are telling of the men being valued only by their work, not their individuality, and comment on the invisibility of the working class.
  5. Realism was tied to emerging socialism by a group concerned with political economy, including Courbet's friend Pierre-Joseph Proudhon, author of La Philosophie de la Misère (The Philosophy of Poverty) (1846); the future president and emperor Louis Napoleon; and Karl Marx (who lived in Paris from 1843-5) and wrote Communist Manifesto in 1848. 
  6. The term Realism was used beginning in the 1830s by artists and critics who felt the renewal of art and literature would happen through a focus on the present, rather than the past/history. Courbet wrote, “To go backwards is to waste effort... Historical art is by nature contemporary. Every age must have its artists, who give expression to it and reproduce it for the future.”
  7. Courbet submitted The Stonebreakers to the Salon of 1850, alongside A Burial at Ornans and 7 other works. 
  8. Likely destroyed during the bombing of Dresden in WWII, it is known through pictures.
Gustave Courbet, A Burial at Ornans, 1849‐50

Realism
  1. Courbet was a French painter who led the Realism movement in 19th-century French painting. Committed to painting only what he could see, he rejected academic convention and the Romanticism of the previous generation. He associated his ideas of realism in art with political anarchism, and, having gained an audience, he promoted democratic and socialist ideas by writing politically motivated essays and dissertations.
  2. Realism advocated by Charles Baudelaire: paint the ordinary aspects of contemporary life and to find in them some grand and epic quality; renounce allegory, nudity, and period costume; large- scale works. In 1846, Baudelaire called for large-scale, serious works that depicted the modern life. Courbet, a friend of Baudelaire, embraced this call and painted A Burial at Ornans, shown in the Salon of 1850-51. It is a monumental representation of a middle-class burial in the French provinces. Unlike David's Death of Socrates (1787) and Delacroix's Death of Sardanapalus (1827-28), Courbet's image neither ennobles nor dramatizes death. Death is shown as what it is - a recurrent and unremarkable event. Courbet's figures are uniformly dressed, suggesting that in the modern age, equality may be achieved.
  3. Courbet's image created a scandal, it was called dull, boring, and criticized for glorifying a trivial subject. Throughout the image are also subtle criticisms of the Church, specifically the apparent alcoholism of one of the officials. Beneath the criticism was also fear stemming from the recent political changes.
  4. Courbet's painting reminded viewers that it was the new republican regime of ordinary, provincial bourgeois that had emerged from the Revolution of 1848 with suffrage rights and political power. He asserts the importance of contemporary imagery rather than historical terms.
  5. Monumental representation of a middle-class burial in the French provinces; Represents the ideas of his time in a contemporary rather than historical terms (ideals = equality) Death is the great equalizer, but here suggested that equality may be achieved during one's lifetime, thanks to revolutions of 1789 and 1848 (Second Republic 1848-1851, universal male suffrage) Men in painting represent large mass of new votes
  6. His realism was most likely influenced by daguerreotype realism and all figures are shown as if of equal importance. The composition's intentionally 'naïf' approach was the perfect antidote to the bombastic air of Couture's Romans of the Decadence (1847) - the hit of the 1847 Salon, the year before the 1848 Revolution.
  7. Brought Courbet instant fame; controversial. Scandalous at the salon. Attacked for being deliberately ugly. C considered it "the burial of Romanticism." Artist looked popular woodcuts, engravings, and lithographs for sense of shadowlessness, stark color contrasts, superimposition of figures, and emotional neutrality.
  8. French Realism was an artistic movement that emerged in France in the 1840s, around the 1848 Revolution. Realists rejected Romanticism, which had dominated French literature and art since the early 19th century. ... The movement aimed to focus on unidealized subjects and events that were previously rejected in art work. Realism was primarily concerned with how things appeared to the eye, rather than containing ideal representations of the world. The popularity of such "realistic" works grew with the introduction of photography—a new visual source that created a desire for people to produce representations which look objectively real. Depicted everyday subjects and situations in contemporary settings, and attempted to depict individuals of all social classes in a similar manner. Gloomy earth toned palettes were used to ignore beauty and idealization that was typically found in art. This movement sparked controversy because it purposefully criticized social values and the upper classes, as well as examining the new values that came along with the industrial revolution. Realist works depicted people of all classes in situations that arise in ordinary life, and often reflected the changes brought by the Industrial and Commercial Revolutions
Robert S. Duncanson, Blue Hole, Flood Waters, Little Miami River, 1851. Collection: Cincinnati Art Museum.

American Landscape Painting / Hudson River School (?)

  1. During the Jacksonian era of the 1820s and 1830s, narrative scenes of everyday life became increasingly popular in the U.S., reflecting the rise of the democratic spirit and the cult of the individual. 
  2. Duncanson began to paint landscapes in earnest beginning in 1848, when he received a commission from Charles Avery, an abolitionist Methodist minister, for the painting Cliff Mine, Lake Superior. Duncanson, who was a Black man born to free Black parents in Pennsylvania, met other abolitionist patrons through Avery as well. 
  3. The Blue Hole, which is just east of Dayton, OH, was a popular site for artists to visit and work en plein air in the 19th century. The Little Miami River is a tributary of the Ohio River east of Cincinnati, where Duncanson had settled a decade earlier.
  4. The figures in the foreground of this oil on canvas composition give scale and a sense of nature's expansive presence around them. This was at the time America's western frontier (c.f. Manifest Destiny). 
  5. Figures like those in foreground were a typical device used by painters of the Hudson River School, who influenced Duncanson’s work (Duncanson admired Thomas Cole’s works and made copies of a number of his paintings). Hudson River School painters emphasized the sense of the sublime in their paintings of American landscapes. (Figures have roots also perhaps in German tradition of landschaft - figures become avatar for the viewer.)
  6. Went on to study painting in Glasgow (1853) and spend time in Montreal during the Civil War, where he helped to inspire a younger generation of artists to form first Canadian school of academic-style landscape painting.
Sir Joseph Paxton, Crystal Palace, London, 1851

Early Industrialist
  1. Britain held the first international industrial exposition in London in 1851. The exhibition coincided with British effort toward establishment of free trade and promote the international sale of Britain’s latest industrial developments. The organizers wanted the architecture to reflect Britain’s technical superiority.
  2. Commission went to Joseph Paxton, a gardener by trade, who modelled the design off of a greenhouse. He presented a design at once large and easy to construct using 3 types of modular units: glass panes set in wooden frames, iron girders on which the panes rested, and cast-iron supporting pillars to construct the building. That each of these units was identical significantly expedited the building process and lowered the cost of construction. They were prefabricated in different locations and then assembled on the spot over the course of 6 months in Hyde Park. This was a breakthrough in technology and design: being able to make buildings that are both gigantic and easy to construct.
  3. With the structure, Paxton demonstrated a highly sophisticated roofing system, “ridge-and furrow,” and ventilation system.
  4. Airiness and exposure of all structural elements perfectly expressed the spirit of the new Industrial age and were unprecedented in a period where elaborately decorated historical revivalist buildings were the norm. It received mixed reviews at the time: some thought it monstrous, others were in awe and anticipated its profound influence on modern architecture; others thought of it as a fancy temporary structure, but not Architecture proper
  5. Each nation had a section for industrial and design products, and any objects/art that showed up their distinct national character (i.e. Indian teepee in the US section). They also included newest industrial machines (esp. of textile industry) and design products for the bourgeois home imitating the style of 18th century aristocracy)
  6. The main body of the building was over 1,848 feet long with a transept 108 feet high.
  7. The Crystal palace established an architectural standard for later international fairs and exhibitions that were likely house in glass conservatories.
  8. The exhibition was criticized for its stylistic eclecticism and homogeneity: all objects looked similar, imitating the European worn-out styles of the past instead of creating a new language of design
Crystal Palace, interior, view of the barrel‐vaulted “transept”, 1851

William Holman Hunt, The Hireling Shepherd, 1851

Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood
1.     English painter who was one of the founders of the pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, modelled in part on the Nazarene movement. The group rejected the artifice of the Mannerist and Baroque artists, and sought a return to an abundance of detail, intense colours and complex composition.
