  1. James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) was an American artist active during the American Gilded Age and based primarily in the United Kingdom. He was averse to sentimentality and moral allusion in painting, and a leading proponent of the credo "art for art's sake".
  2. His artworks were often named after music compositions. This one is “nocturne” others are “symphonies,” “harmonies” etc. indicating they are artistic arrangements made for their aesthetic value. 
  3. Painting of fireworks falling over a riverbank, trees, dark blue sky. Painted in a limited color scheme, not a realistic landscape but an evocation of the magical mood created by the glowing fireworks in an evening sky. (Tonalism:  Between 1880 and 1915, dark, neutral hues such as gray, brown or blue, often dominated compositions by artists associated with the style. During the late 1890s, American art critics began to use the term "tonal" to describe these works.)
  4. This painting was the subject of the trial Ruskin v. Whistler. When Ruskin accused Whistler in the press of ripping off his buyers for charging 200 guineas for the painting and accused him of “throwing a pot of paint in the face of the public.” In many ways, the defendant in the case was not simply the art critic John Ruskin, but art—especially modern art—itself. What was in the balance here? One weighty question concerned the role of art in society. Ruskin believed that art possessed the power to improve society. For him, this was accomplished chiefly through an artwork’s ability to represent nature faithfully. Whistler’s attempt to capture the dazzling effects of a fireworks display over the Thames through startling, explosive brushwork defied the critic’s understanding of nature as a product of divine creation. Whistler believed an artwork’s usefulness detracted from its aesthetic purpose. Whistler won the suit, but still ended up bankrupt.

Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi,
Liberty Enlightening the World (Statue of Liberty), 1875‐1884

French Republican Monumental Sculpture
  1. Intended to commemorate a century of friendship between US and France. Idea for a gift of monument from French to US conceived by Republicans during Second Empire, fundraising began after Paris Commune (1871). Third Republic was particularly big on commissioning patriotic monumental sculptures as public exemplars of its motto, “moral order”.
  2. Bartholdi received commission and chose Bedloe’s island (now Liberty Island), from which he felt the statue would be most visible. He designed a monumental sculpture responding to the site: because it would generally be seen from afar, he designed a simple, Classical form with a dramatic silhouette.  
  3. The iconography of Bartholdi’s allegory of Liberty was not traditional (helmet with sunray spikes, tablet, torch). Helmet: Americans supposedly disliked Liberty’s usual French Phrygian bonnet, associated with slavery and radicalism. May have pulled idea from the Colossus of Rhodes, lost sculpture of sun god Helos that stood astride harbor of ancient city (one of 7 wonders). Reference “enlightenment,” echoed in torch. American as a beacon of freedom. (statue faced Europe: America set example for the Old World in particular) Tablet: law, which protects people’s freedoms, prevents freedom from becoming anarchy. Inscribed JULY IV MDCCLXXVI (July 4, 1776).
  4. Over 150’ tall” could not be cast in bronze. Used a new industrial method of production: beaten copper sheets that were riveted together and attached with iron braces to central skeleton. Architects Viollet-de-Duc and later Gustave Eiffel were technical consultants. Made in Paris, dismantled for shipping. 
  5. Statue's massive arm and torch at the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia in 1876. Afterwards the pieces were displayed in Madison Square Park, New York City until 1882 to assist in fundraising. 
  6. Statue’s base designed by American architect Richard Morris Hunt; statue installed in 1886.

Gustave Moreau, Salomé Dancing before Herod, 1876
Armand Hammer Museum of Art and  Cultural Center, Los Angeles

French Symbolism / Orientalism
1. Symbolism is a movement during the Belle Époque (1890-1914) that rejects materialism and realism (and their goal of accurate observation) to turn instead to spirituality and the imagination; harked back to a Romanticist tradition
2. Symbolism believed that there was a more meaningful spiritual reality beneath the physical world and that it could be communicated only through art; symbolism was not the observation of the world but the painting of ideas, a representation of the imaginary
3. Moreau and his contemporary Redon experienced a sudden upsurge of public interest through the publication of Huysmans’ novel A rebours [Against the Grain], in which the main character retreats into a private world surrounded by the works of Moreau and Redon
4. Depicts a biblical story: Salome dancing in front of Herod in return for the head of John the Baptists
5. A romanticized rendering of a biblical story where the femme fatale is embodied in the Oriental other; the background is a composite of various orientalist spaces
6. Moreau’s is a literary symbolism in which the underlying meaning was inherent in the subject matter (different from the symbolism of Van Gogh or Gaugin);  imaginative interpretations of literary (biblical, mythological) subjects
7. Not unlike academic history painting in its subject matter (which is derived from the Bible or mythology) but unprecedented in form: use of color and chiaroscuro to create atmospheric effect suggesting the spellbinding eroticism of Salome’s dance
8. This Symbolist turn to spirituality and the imaginary occurred at a time when psychiatry saw a rapid development as a medical discipline (by Charcot and Freud in 1880s and 90s), and a revival of religiosity and esotericism to respond to the psychological pressures of the fin de siècle; symbolism can be understood in the context of such a turn to the spiritual (Moreau) and psychology (Redon), the latter anticipating the Surrealist movement by some 50 years
William Morris, Detail of Pimpernel wallpaper, 1876

Victorian
  1. William Morris was the driving force behind a new design firm, Morris, Marshal Faulkner & Co. and shared John Ruskin and Augustus Pugin’s interest in medieval art and architecture. He idealized the middle ages as a time of a democratic art form, when art was made by the people for the people, and sought to replicate this kind of socialist art in his own designs. But because it was handpainted it was incredibly expensive, and thus in conflict with his democratic ideal of art.
  2. To counter the negative effects of industrial mass production, Morris became a staunch advocate of handmade products. He inspired the Arts and Crafts Movement, an international movement that rejected machine projection, promoting instead the practice of preindustrial craft techniques
  3. His wallpaper designs were block printed and then colored by hand. They typically used a simple and stylized flower motif inspired by traditional folk art. Each print was based on a specific flower from British gardens, rather than that elaborate, exotic, unnamed plants, seeking to establish a distinctly British design. 
  4. He created structure through his designs by building strong, rhythmic and fluid lines from the shapes of leaves, vines and branches, and he frequently superimposed the main pattern over a smaller, recessive background pattern to fill the design space. This was quite at odds with the contemporary design fashion for illusion and exaggeration.
Auguste Renoir, Ball at the Moulin de la Galette, 1876

Impressionist figure painting
1.     While Realist painters like Courbet chose to represent the working life of peasants, the Impressionists chose subject matter depicting the bourgeois class at the their leisure. Impressionist pictures appear less politically charged as a result, placing emphasis on the modern leisure life. Leisure was new phenomenon on the late 19th century, and a by-product of capitalism; the middle class was no longer forced to work throughout the year in order to make a living. Bourgeois women, who were not expected to work at all became the protagonists of impressionist leisure. 
2.     This scene depicts a popular cafe in Montmartre with an open air seating area where locals came and danced on Sundays, along with a variety of students and artists. Renoir was drawn to the mixed character of the crowd. George Riviere, a friend of Renoir’s, notes that the women in this image, whom the artist had coaxed into posing for him, were of working class origin, the type who would normally frequent such dances (Montmartre was a poor, rundown area).
3.     Though it was partially painted on the spot, Renoir also made various preliminary studies. The framing of the scene in which the figures on the sides are cut off, gives the impression that it continues beyond its bounds and that this is a slice of reality.
4.     Renoir was the first to apply Impressionistic brushwork of their landscapes to figure paintings and genre scenes. Here, the brushwork helps animate the dance moment, creating a sense of the arbitrary moment. It also creates a break away from the Academic tradition: has no one focal point in the composition.
5.     Renoir was keen to present the painting as a genuine scene of Parisian life. However, this has been contended to untrue: described as a contrived image, largely populated by Renoirs middle class friends enjoying the company of lower class women– the image of carefree enjoyment is essential an ideal.
James Abbott McNeill Whistle r, Harmony in Blue and Gold: The Peacock Room, 1876‐77

Aesthetic Movement/Anglo-Japanese Style

  1. Whistler was one of the most important artists of the Aesthetic movement, a proponent of art for art's sake.
  2. It is considered an Aesthetic movement masterpiece because of its exotic nature and colors, a decadent 19th-century interior in the Anglo-Japanese style that survived intact and reflects the wider interest in Eastern design and culture characteristic of the time (Japonisme).
  3. Whistler turned the room into a total work of art; it was an unsettling and seductive environment as he painted every surface (shutters and ceiling too) in luminous shades of green, gold, and blue, contributing to a lavish but aesthetically coordinated whole.
  4. Whistler's painting The Princess from the Land of Porcelain, hangs over the mantel as the centerpiece. It was from a series of costume pictures undertaken in mid-1860s in which western models appear in Asian dress, surrounded by Chinese and Japanese objects from Whistler's own collections.
  5. The room was designed to accommodate the blue and white Chinese porcelain collection of English shipping magnate Frederick Leyland, a long-time patron of Whistler's, held in the dining room of his London house.  However, Whistler acted on his own without a commission, leading to a fallout between them as Leyland paid half of what Whistler requested after completion (equivalent of 200k pounds!).
  6. Hurt and angry, he painted the rear wall with a vindictive allegorical mural titled Art and Money; or, the Story of the Room, depicting Leyland as a stingy peacock made of money and Whistler as the poor peacock with silver crest feathers that refer to his distinctive white forelock.
  7. After Leyland died, Charles Lang Freer, a railroad-car manufacturer, acquired it. Freer installed it in his Detroit mansion as a setting for his own collection of Asian pottery. He bequeathed it to the Smithsonian in 1906, where it now lives in the Freer Gallery of Art.
  8. The room underscores Freer's belief that "all works of art go together, whatever their period." His faith in cross-cultural aesthetic harmonies achieved its ultimate expression in the Freer Gallery itself, where Whistler's Peacock Room is located between galleries of Chinese, Korean and American art, embodying the meeting of East and West, making aesthetic connections between art, decoration, paintings, ceramics, Europe, America, and Asia.

Edward Coley Burne‐Jones, Golden Stairs, 1876-­‐80
Tate Britain, London

Aesthetic Movement

  1. Edward Coley Burne-Jones (1833-1898) was a student of Dante Gabriel Rossetti and a collaborator with William Morris. He worked in the Pre-Raphaelite style and then focused on decorative art with Morris and created stained glass designs. Golden Stairs is from later in his career when he focused on the Aesthetic movement. 
  2. The Aesthetic Movement was guided by complex ideas, but most boiled down to 2 ideas set forth by Walter Horatio Pater (1839-1894): 1) Art is superior to nature. 2) Content is not as important as form. Often focused on the figure of a beautiful woman. (See Rossetti’s Monna Vanna)
  3. Burne-Jones's aim in art is best given in his own words, written to a friend: “I mean by a picture a beautiful, romantic dream of something that never was, never will be – in a light better than any light that ever shone – in a land no one can define or remember, only desire – and the forms divinely beautiful – and then I wake up, with the waking of Brynhild.”
  4. 18 women in this painting, all with musical instruments, some dating to the Middle Ages, but there is no concrete narrative or story illustrated. 
  5. Most striking for its formal qualities: subtle color, semicircular composition, contrast between hard lines of architecture and soft contour of feminine qualities. 
  6. Musical instruments hearken to the origins of the early Aesthetic ideas of Pater who thought music was the perfect aesthetic art.

Claude Monet, Gare St‐Lazare, Paris, 1877
Fogg Art Museum, Harvard Art Museum, Cambridge, MA

Impressionism
  1. Exhibited three paintings of the Gare Saint-Lazare at 3rd Impressionist exhibition of 1877. Made 12 paintings of station total, seen from various viewpoints at different times of day. 
  2. Emphasis on quality of light (here, seen through smoke): typical of Impressionism. (According to Cézanne, “Monet is only an eye, but my God what an eye!”)
  3. Shift from Monet’s previous focus on natural/pastoral scenes, painted en plein aire
  4. Series presents viewers with spectacles of the train station and chaotic modern public life
  5. He worked on all the paintings at the same time, and sometimes he leaned the stretched canvases against each other while the paint was still wet. 
  6. Thick impasto of paint in varying hues: large visible brush strokes only make sense viewed from afar: Impressionist rejection of Academic technique. 
  7. Early iteration of Monet’s series of the same subject depicted at different times of day/in different light conditions, began in earnest in 1880s (see: Haystacks, Rouen Cathedral)
Eadweard Muybridge, Horse in Motion, 1878

Stop-action photography
1. Muybridge was a British photographer working at a time when Impressionists had become interested in new forms of vision and innovations in composition, paining casual glimpses of fleeting reality as if taking photographic snapshots, as opposed to artificially arranged compositions
2. Edgar Degas copied several of Muybridge’s horse studies (reproduced in the French journal La Nature in 1878) for his own horse paintings (i.e. Jockey’s before the Start 1878) to more accurately convey the image of a horse in motion
3. Horse race tracks were modern sites par excellence, where the fashionable crowds gathered for leisure and engaged in the activity of watching, an eminently modern activity
4. In these stop-action photographs, Muybridge was attempting to answer the question: does a galloping horse ever become fully airborne? Leland Stanford (former California governor and railroad tycoon) commissioned Muybridge to prove that the answer is yes.
5. Muybridge set up 12 cameras along Stanford’s estate and developed a way to take photos with only a fraction of a second of exposure; when running by, horses triggered trip wires connected to the cameras which took photos in rapid succession
6. The answer is yes, for a split second (frame 3): too fleeting to be seen by the naked eye but apparent through photography; new purpose of the medium of photography: capturing truth through technology
7. Technological and conceptual breakthrough: capturing a span of time by a succession of singular instants (compare the philosophy of Henri Bergson)
8. His stop-action technique was an early form of animation that helped pave the way for the motion-picture industry about a decade later
Mary Cassatt, Little Girl in a Blue Armchair, 1878

Impressionism
  1. American artist Cassatt studied in France under Gérôme, Couture and others and while there was invited by Degas to join a group of artists who were exhibited independently outside of the Salon, which came to be known at the Impressionist Exhibitions. She exhibited Little Girl in a Blue Chair at the 4th Impressionist Exhibition
  2. The dominance of the overstuffed furniture with its vibrant blue upholstery captures an odd sense of restlessness and languorousness, both matched by the girl’s pose. There is a rebellious, devil-may-care attitude in her comfortably lounging form.
  3. She seeks to recreate the feeling of disorientation and tiresomeness a child feels within the social constraints of an adult’s world, a world that seems almost oppressively gendered. Here, Cassatt presents a radically new image of childhood, and domesticity in general.
  4. The similarities between Cassat’s and Degas’s work, certainly in this period, are also striking. In its asymmetrical composition, the casual, unposed treatment of the sitter, the weightiness and solidity of its forms in contrast to that grey mercurial dollop of negative space, its use of cropping and loose brushwork, as well as the interest in the private moment that we find so often in his pastels, the hallmarks of Degas’s work can clearly be found in Little Girl in a Blue Armchair.
  5. Influence of Japonisme. As a collector of Japanese prints, she drew inspiration from their patterns and asymmetric structures, influencing the asymmetrical composition, raised viewpoint, shallow space, and abrupt cropping of the scene.

Odilon Redon, Vision, plate 8 of In the Dream, 1879
Art Institute of Chicago

Symbolism
1.     French symbolist painter, printmaker, draughtsman. Anticipated Surrealism by about fifty years and pursued it through avenues of fantasy and free association. Explores psychology through dreams and memories.
2.     Slow to venture into the public artistic arena, he did not launch his career until 1879 when he published an album of ten lithographs, In the Dream. This eighth print from the series is typical of the rest of his work, which often show eyeballs or disembodied heads floating in space. 
3.     In this print, a man and woman wandering through a colossal architectural space come upon a huge eyeball hovering between two columns. What makes the print intriguing is that it appears to suggest the occurrence of an intensifying series of visual experiences that come closer to an ‘ultimate’ vision that in itself remains invisible (the vision of the viewer of the work, the vision of the couple, and finally the vision of the eyeball directed towards the sky, appearing to catch a glimpse of something so bright that it cause it to be aglow in halo of light. 
4.     Draws from Christian imagery, most notably in Baroque paintings of visionary saints, where their eyes are opened wide as they catch a glimpse of the divine. 
5.     His hovering eyes and heads have also been associated with the contemporary fascination with hot air balloons as well as the popularization of astronomy manifested in numerous articles in family and children’s magazines.
